cards.front: What is the difference between a **scalar** and a **vector** quantity?
cards.back: A scalar has magnitude only; a vector has both magnitude and direction.

cards.front: Is **distance** a scalar or a vector?
Is **displacement** a scalar or a vector?
Is **speed** a scalar or a vector?
Is **velocity** a scalar or a vector?
Is **acceleration** a scalar or a vector?
What is the formula for the final velocity of an object with uniform acceleration?
What is the formula for the displacement of an object with uniform acceleration?
What is the 'timeless' kinematic equation?
What is the formula for displacement using average velocity?
What is **free-fall**?
cards.back: The motion of an object solely under the influence of gravity, with no air resistance.

cards.front: What is the value of acceleration due to gravity on Earth?
What is the acceleration of a projectile at its highest point?
What is the horizontal acceleration of a projectile (ignoring air resistance)?
What is a **projectile**?
cards.back: An object that is thrown or launched into the air and is subject only to the force of gravity.

cards.front: How does the time it takes for an object to fall from a height compare to an identical object thrown horizontally from the same height?
cards.back: The time is the same, as the vertical motion is independent of the horizontal motion.

cards.front: What is the slope of a **position-time graph**?
What does a horizontal line on a position-time graph represent?
What does a straight, sloped line on a position-time graph represent?
What is the slope of a **velocity-time graph**?
What does a horizontal line on a velocity-time graph represent?
What does a straight, sloped line on a velocity-time graph represent?
What is the area under a **velocity-time graph**?
What is the area under an **acceleration-time graph**?
What is **terminal velocity**?
cards.back: The constant speed that a freely falling object eventually reaches when the resistance of the medium (air) prevents further acceleration.

cards.front: What is **uniform acceleration**?
cards.back: A constant rate of change of velocity.

cards.front: What is the **trajectory** of a projectile?
cards.back: The path that the projectile follows, which is a parabola.

cards.front: What is the **range** of a projectile?
cards.back: The total horizontal distance traveled by the projectile.

cards.front: What is **relative velocity**?
cards.back: The velocity of an object with respect to another object or frame of reference.

cards.front: If a car is traveling at $$100\text{ km/h}$$ and a truck is traveling at $$80\text{ km/h}$$ in the same direction, what is the car's speed relative to the truck?
What is the vertical velocity of a projectile at its maximum height?
What is the horizontal velocity of a projectile at its maximum height?
cards.back: It is constant and equal to its initial horizontal velocity.

cards.front: What is the significance of the sign (+/-) in kinematic quantities?
cards.back: It indicates the direction of the vector.

cards.front: What is the difference between instantaneous and average velocity?
cards.back: Instantaneous velocity is at a specific moment in time; average velocity is over a time interval.

cards.front: When can the kinematic equations be used?
cards.back: Only when the acceleration is uniform (constant).

cards.front: What is the shape of a position-time graph for an object with constant acceleration?
What does the initial velocity ($$v_i$$) represent in a free-fall problem?
cards.back: The velocity at the moment the object begins to fall (often zero).

cards.front: In a kinematic problem, why is the negative sign for acceleration crucial?
cards.back: It indicates that the object is slowing down or accelerating in the opposite direction.

cards.front: What is the relationship between the time to reach the peak and the total flight time for a projectile launched and landing at the same height?
cards.back: The time to the peak is exactly half of the total flight time.

cards.front: What is a **frame of reference**?
cards.back: A system of coordinates used to describe the position and motion of an object.
